entry.title: Re: How to rewrite this ABAP SQL join via the CDS associations and SQL Path Expression?
entry.content:
Instead of defining the SQL Path Expression in the FROM part, just have it in the list of selected columns:

SELECT DISTINCT PrelimBillingDocument,
                i_prelimbillingdocumentitem~\_salesdocument\_zzpurchaseorderitemacctassign[ MANY TO EXACT ONE ]-costcenter
  FROM I_PrelimBillingDocumentItem
  WHERE PrelimBillingDocument = 'PBD0000061'
    AND i_prelimbillingdocumentitem~\_salesdocument\_zzpurchaseorderitemacctassign[ MANY TO EXACT ONE ]-costcenter <> ' '
  INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_billing_doc_to_cost_center).

entry.title: How to use Version Management with Github Repository
entry.content:
The Version Management application allows you to manage versions of BI resources that exist in the BI Platform repository. 
We have an Option to use the Version Management Application to Use Subversion or Git/ GitHub as a repository.
In this Blog, we will be checking on how to use the Version Management with Github as an repository

Downloading and Installing the GIT Application

  • Download the GIT application from : https://git-scm.com/ 
  • Download and install the GIT application on the BO Server. We will need this to configure later.

Configuration of Github 

  • Create an Account on Github - > https://github.com/ 
  • Create a Public repository on the Github which we want to use for Version Management.

Token Generation in Github and Maintaining the default branch

  1. Navigate to the Profile on the https://github.com/settings/profile
  2. Scroll Down to <> Developer Setting.
  3. Next Select the Personal Access Tokens > Tokens ( classic)
  4. Generate new token ( classic)

     

  5. Under Scopes Select Repo:

To check the default Branch. Navigate to Settings and then Repository : https://github.com/settings/repositories 

Master is been set as default

 

Configuring Version Management in CMC to use Github

  1. In CMC Home page, select Applications.
  2. Select Version Management.
  3. Choose Git from the Version Management Systems list.
  4. Click the checkbox Use as Default VMS.
  5. Under Protocol use HTTP(s). (HTTP is used if you want to completely use local GIT)
  6. Below are the parameters that needs to be maintained. 


    Parameters  Details
    User nameEnter the username of the Github account that was used to create repository
    GitHub personal access tokens (classic)Enter the token generated above from Github
    GitHub Remote Repository URLEnter the link to the Repository that was created on Github. <https://github.com/<username>/<Repository Name>
    Workspace DirectoryEnter the Path where you want to save your workspace.
    Repository NameEnter a name for your Github repository. Should be the same that is been created in Github. <Repository Name>
    GIT Install PathEnter the install directory of Git. <install_dir>\Git\bin
    Default Branch NameEnter the Default Branch name that is been maintained in your profile on github. 

  7. Once all the Details are maintained, Click on SAVE
  8. Restart the APS hosting the Version Management Services. 
  9. Navigate to the CMC > and access the Version Management Application

entry.title: SAP MDG: Based on Grouping, Tax Number is Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note: This blog does not include execution screenshots.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to make the Tax Number field mandatory for specific Groupings. The logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Target Groupings: ZSGP, ZSGC
  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 001
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: Tax Number is Mandatory !!!
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the specified groupings are selected, the system enforces the presence of a Tax Number and raises a custom message if it's missing.

Code:

 

  METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
    CALL METHOD io_model->read_entity_data_all
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname    = 'BP_HEADER'            
        if_active      = abap_false            
        i_crequest     = id_crequest            " Change Request
      IMPORTING
        et_data_entity = DATA(lt_data).        " Data for Entity Types
    .
    READ TABLE lt_data INTO DATA(ls_data) WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = ' ' struct = 'KATTR'.
    ASSIGN ls_data-r_t_data->* TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lt_data>).
    LOOP AT <lt_data> ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_data>).
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'BU_GROUP' OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_group>).
      IF <lv_group> IS ASSIGNED AND
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGP' OR
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGC'.
        READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_TAXNUM' struct = 'KATTR'.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          et_message = VALUE #( ( msgid = 'ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS' msgty = 'E' msgno = '001' ) ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.


SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Re: PO header and item text do not appear in printed form...
entry.content:
When I said ‚Äúeach text type must be assigned to the output type and language,‚Äù I didn‚Äôt mean there‚Äôs a customizing table where you explicitly list every language. In Purchasing text determination, you only define which text IDs (header, item, etc.) are relevant for output. The language comes from the output message language (NAST-SPRAS) at runtime.

So the checks are in two places:

Path: SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Messages ‚Üí Texts for Purchase Orders ‚Üí Define Texts for Purchase Orders. Here you assign which text IDs (e.g. F01 Header Note, F02 Terms, etc.) are pulled into the PO form. This customizing is language‚Äëindependent. It just says ‚Äúinclude this text ID in the output.‚Äù

The actual language handling happens in the form (Smartform/Adobe/SAPscript). At runtime, the system looks for the text in the message language (NAST-SPRAS). If the text exists in that language, it prints. If not, it‚Äôs skipped. That‚Äôs why EN/FR/DE work (texts exist in those languages), but IT doesn‚Äôt.

If you ask me where to check for Italian, go to SE75, and check if your PO text object (e.g. EKKO/EKPO) has Italian maintained. Go to SE63 and check if the text modules used in the Smartform have Italian translations. Go to NAST table and confirm the message really has SPRAS = IT. Go to Smartform and check if the text elements have Italian maintained.

entry.title: Intelligent Application - Why is Data stored twice in SAP BDC (Object Store & Ingestion Space)?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

When we install an intelligent Application in SAP Business Data Cloud,
Data products gets data from Object Store into Ingestion layer(Datasphere Space).
So data from S/4HANA is stored twice in SAP Business Data cloud:

  1. 1st its store in Object Store as a File.
  2. 2nd its stored in SAP Datasphere Space via Replication flow taking Object Store as a source.

I wanted to understand what is the advantage of using 2 storages which is causing data duplication?

SAP could have directly stored data from S/4HANA to Datasphere ingestion Space or just share data from Object store to Datasphere space.
Can anyone please explain this strategy/process?

entry.title: Enhanced Variant Table Handling in PMEVC: Excel Download and Upload of Variant Tables
entry.content:
The Product Modeling Environment for Variant Configuration (PMEVC) now supports the download and upload of variant tables, even when they contain multi-value cells. This new capability allows users to copy and work with variant tables more efficiently, enhancing both performance and user experience.

Download Variant Tables with Multi-Value Cells

Previously, downloading variant tables containing multi-value cells to Microsoft Excel was not possible. With the implementation of the SAP Note 3547198, this limitation has been overcome. Here are the highlights of this feature:

  • Multi-Value Cell Handling: Values within multi-value cells are now downloaded with a line break as a separator.
  • File Format: The variant table content is downloaded in the modern .xlsx format, which improves usability and compatibility.
  • Numeric Value Conversion: Numeric values are converted from the user setting format to the internal format for consistent representation.
  • Wildcard Support: Wildcards in variant tables of processing mode Advanced Variant Configuration are downloaded as blank cells.
  • Display Setting: Characteristic values are downloaded based on the display setting in PMEVC, either as values or descriptions. However, characteristics will always be downloaded as value, i.e., using their language-independent name.

How to Download a Variant Table with Multi-value Cells

In the VC Modeling Environment, access the Contents tab of the variant table detail screen and select the dropdown button for export. From the dropdown list select Spreadsheet.

Export

Export -> Spreadsheet

Enter the name of the file to be downloaded and save it.

Resulting Excel file content:

Excel Export with Wildcard (empty cell), Multiple Values per Cell and Interval Value

 

Upload Variant Table Content Directly from Excel

Until now, importing variant table content from Excel required a manual copy and paste process, e.g., CTRL+C and CTRL+V in Windows. With the SAP Note 3562947, users can now directly upload content from a local MS Excel file to a variant table in PMEVC. Key aspects of this feature include:

  • Direct Upload Button: A new button on the PMEVC variant table detail screen allows for direct uploads from the first sheet of an MS Excel file.
  • Error Handling: During the import process, value checks for format and validity are performed, and any incorrect cells are displayed in the message list with exact cell positions.
  • Content Overwrite Option: Users can choose to overwrite existing content or cancel the upload process.

Upload Requirements

To ensure a successful upload, the following conditions must be met:

  1. File Format: The upload file must be in an Office Open XML format (.xlsx, .xlsm, .xls).
  2. Variant Table Status: The variant table status needs to be Released to allow content changes.
  3. Worksheet Content: The first worksheet of the Excel workbook is considered for upload, with the table content starting with technical names of all columns/characteristics in the defined order.
  4. Row and Column Limits: The number of rows to be uploaded is limited to 99,999, and the number of columns to 999.
  5. Value Format: Values in the Excel sheet must be maintained as characteristic values, and specific formatting requirements apply to different cell types.

Formatting Requirements per Cell Type

Characteristic Type of Column

Cell Format in Excel

Format Requirements

Examples

Character

General/Text

No further restrictions than defined for characteristic

string value

Numeric/Currency

General/Text

SAP's internal number format, this means no thousand separator, decimal separator '.'

1234.56789, -423.19112, 123

Number/Currency/Percentage/Accounting/Fraction/Scientific/...

General/Text

No restrictions

 

Date

General/Text

Gregorian date format:
YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY.MM.DD, YYYY/MM/DD, MM/DD/YYYY, DD.MM.YYYY, MM-DD-YYYY

2023-02-18, 2021.07.04, 2020/12/25, 11/25/2022, 05.06.2019, 10-29-2021

Time

General/Text

24 Hour Format: HH:MM:SS

14:23:45, 09:12:01, 23:59:59

Multi-value cells

General/Text (required)

Equivalent to the requirements of the corresponding characteristic value with "General" format. Values must be separated by a line break (Excel shortcut: Alt + Enter to separate values)

aaa
bbb
ccc

Interval

General/Text

Equivalent to the requirements of the corresponding characteristic value with "General" format. The following symbols can be used to construct intervals: Equal '=', hyphen '-', comparison signs '<' and '>', left-open, right-open interval: > a - < b, left-open, right-closed interval: > a - b, left-closed, right-open interval: a - < b, left-closed, right-closed interval: a - b, left-open interval: > a, left-closed interval: >= a, right-open interval: < b, right-closed interval: <= b

 

 

How to Upload a Variant Table with Multi-value Cells

Open the detail screen of a new or existing variant table and access the Contents tab. You can also use the copy function of the working set to create a variant table with the same columns.

Copy a Variant Table

To upload content, you need to change into Edit mode and select the button Upload.

Upload

Select the Excel file from which you want to upload the content. If any content previously existed, you must decide whether you want to overwrite it or cancel the upload process.

Uploaded with Wildcard, Multi-Value Cell, and Interval Value

These enhancements to variant table handling in the PMEVC mark a substantial improvement in usability and efficiency. The ability to download and upload variant tables with multi-value cells, coupled with direct file uploads from Excel, streamlines workflows and reduces manual data handling. By implementing these SAP Notes, users can now enjoy a more seamless and efficient experience when working with variant tables.

For more detailed information, refer to the SAP Note 3547198 for export functionality and to the SAP Note 3562947 for import functionality.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build ‚Äì Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q3, we delivered several innovations across AI-powered development, ABAP project creation, modernized SAPUI5 and advanced mobile capabilities. SAP Build also reached a significant milestone with the introduction of MCP servers, allowing developers to boost productivity further with AI agents. 

Check these out in our Top 10 Release Highlights from Q3 2025! 

AI-powered development

1. Empowering developers with MCP Tools for SAP Build 

Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers are now available for the following technologies: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori. This is a huge step forward for developers working with popular IDEs and coding assistants like GitHub Copilot, Cursor and more. With these MCP servers, we‚Äôre now providing a comprehensive set of tools designed to optimize your development workflow across various SAP technologies.

Learn more in the blog post.

2. SAP HANA Cloud SQL Statement Generation in Joule

Directly in SAP Build Code, the Joule panel now offers the new command /hana-sql-gen, which enables the generation of SQL statements from natural language directly in the panel. The generated statements can be reviewed and refined in the Joule panel. Suitable SQL statements can be either copied to a SQL console or directly executed inside the Joule panel after selecting a database connection on which to run the statement.

3. Expanded AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone continues to expand its AI capabilities, bringing new built-in features to an intelligent workspace with accelerated decision-making and improved employee experiences:

  • Integration of Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition: By bringing Joule into SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, users can now enjoy the power of Joule within their digital workplace. This eliminates the hassle of system-hopping, reduces time wasted on searching for information, and allows employees to focus on what is important. (Note: Available in early October)
  • AI-powered text and comment generation: This enables employees to quickly create, summarize, and engage with workplace content. For example, project managers can generate project status updates in minutes, ensuring their team members stay aligned.

Learn more in the blog post.

Enhanced App Development & Automation

4. Availability of SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed 

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. This means app developers can test their UI code for compliance to SAPUI5 best practices. This helps to future-proof an SAP Fiori app for future SAPUI5 versions and work on deprecated/outdated code. Developers can also provide feedback to the UI5 team.

Learn more in the blog post.

5. Create full-stack ABAP projects in SAP Business Application Studio

You can now create full-stack ABAP projects or open an existing ABAP CSN as a project in SAP Business Application Studio. You can also model your application using the CDS Graphical Modeler and generate ABAP development objects. By leveraging high productivity tools, this significantly accelerates time-to-market, improves collaboration and provides a standardized, compliant approach to building extensions.

Learn more in the Help Portal. ..And stay tuned! We‚Äôll share more about this topic at SAP TechEd 2025.

6. Maintenance project for released process automation projects

For process automation, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to create dedicated project versions based on an existing released version. This allows process owners to maintain parallel editable versions while keeping the latest version in place, enabling teams to focus on solving a problem without redoing everything from scratch.

Learn more in the Help Portal.

7. Holistic process views for requestors and participants

Now customers can benefit from dedicated, holistic views across their automated processes. The views provide information about natively running instances across multiple processes and workflows without any external configuration.

8. Outbox functionality for tasks in SAP Task Center

SAP Task Center, which provides a seamless user experience for accessing open tasks, now lets you view completed tasks in an outbox. This provides a complete view of historical data while reducing support requests and efforts around process automation instances.

New innovations for mobile

9. Support for new site experience in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition 

Employees accessing their workspace content via SAP Mobile Start can now enjoy a new view mode with a more flexible structuring of content. They can quickly view workspace updates, company news or project dashboards, making it easier to organize and consume information in a personalized way. (Note: Available in early October)

 

10. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

As the native mobile entry point to all SAP business apps and content, SAP Mobile Start has released several new innovations that simplify employee tasks and optimize their user experience:

  • SAP Document AI integration: Allows users to upload documents and photos for automated processing. This streamlines document handling, cuts down manual work and ensures data accuracy throughout operations.
  • Enhanced push notifications with more detailed information: Load and display context-specific details directly in the push notification, providing more meaningful and informative messages.
  • Simplified onboarding via deep link: IT teams can invite users to onboard to SAP Mobile Start via an email or message and provide a deep link that the users can use to initiate a simplified onboarding process.
  • Top news on start screen: Shows the most important news in a larger format on top of the Start screen.

Learn more in the latest blog post and Help Portal.

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Webinar on October 8th as we dive deeper into MCP servers in CAP, SAP Mobile Start innovations, and much more!

Sign up today for your preferred option:
üåêOctober 8th, 9:00-10:00am CEST (EMEA/APJ friendly): Register here
üåêOctober 8th, 5:00-6:00pm CEST (Americas friendly): Register here

entry.title: Day 1 EHS & Product Compliance InfoDays
entry.content:
Day 1 began with a great keynote by SAP Chief Sustainability and Commercial Officer Sophia Mendelsohn about how, due to the rapidly evolving business landscape, integrating sustainability with Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Product Compliance (PC) is crucial. AI technology offers innovative solutions to enhance this connection, particularly in scaling Scope 3 emissions calculations and transforming supply chain compliance.

Data is the backbone of effective decision-making. By consolidating data from both within SAP systems and outside, businesses can harness a comprehensive view of their operations. This integration acts as a "quantity play," enabling organizations to leverage data for strategic advantage. SAP AI Joule facilitates this by transforming complex data into intuitive visuals, making it easier to understand the impact of carbon reduction initiatives and supply chain adjustments.

 

AI is revolutionizing traditional manual tasks, bringing them into the 21st century. With tools like Joule, businesses can take steps like creating a safer working environment, reducing machine downtime, and saving valuable employee time. This modernization not only enhances operational efficiency but also contributes to a more sustainable and compliant business model.

 

Incorporating AI into your business strategy is not just about keeping up with technological advancements; it's about creating a future where sustainability and efficiency go hand in hand.

Next up was Ralf Coenning discussing the Product Compliance Roadmap and Strategy, and how ensuring product compliance is more crucial than ever. He kicked off with a brief overview of product compliance, breaking it down into key areas: Product Marketability and Component Compliance, Dangerous Goods Management, and Compliance Document Management, which includes safety data sheets and labeling.

The shift towards a highly automated system is a game-changer, embedding regulatory content to keep processes swift and up to date, protecting both your brand and your bottom line. This automation allows businesses to expand their compliance scope, collaborating with partners to access regulatory content beyond the embedded confines. Excitingly, more flexibility is on the horizon, enhancing partner content integration.

 

With the latest functionality on S/4 HANA, product compliance is transitioning from traditional systems to modern, user-friendly solutions. Whether directly within Product Compliance or through partner solutions, these advancements promise a streamlined, efficient approach to managing compliance.

Missed the session? No worries, you can still sign up (see the link below) and get watch on demand or just take a look at the slides used by the presenters. Today, you can join me and many others learning more about Product Compliance and the latest innovations around dangerous goods, product marketability, safety data sheets and labeling. 

https://imsap.co/6048A6bJE

entry.title: Manage Service Order app is not visible in Public Cloud
entry.content:
We would like to enable the ‚ÄúManage Service Order‚Äù app for a user.

We have already assigned all the required business catalogs and roles to the user as referenced from the SAP Fiori App Library.

However, the app is still not displayed in the user‚Äôs launchpad, and when searching in the Fiori Launchpad, it cannot be found.

Why the Manage Service Order app is not visible even after assigning the necessary roles and catalogs?

 

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Manage Service Order app is not visible in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Good day,  

Thank you for raising this issue.   

The behavior you are observing is expected and has been documented in **SAP KBA 2876916**. The ‚ÄúManage Service Order (F3571A)‚Äù app is delivered as a **Smart Business KPI app**. By design, such apps do not appear in the Fiori Launchpad search. 2876916 - Search function - Manage Service Orders app is missing

As a workaround, the app can be found via the **App Finder** and then added to the user‚Äôs home page for easier access.  

Hope this clarifies the situation.  

Kind regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Driving Business Transformation with the SAP Integrated Tool Chain ‚Äî An Architect‚Äôs View
entry.content:
As a TOGAF-certified professional and SAP BTP Certified Solution Architect working in Application Lifecycle Management (ALM), I have helped many organizations with their digital transformation journeys. One thing I‚Äôve learned is this: success in transformation doesn‚Äôt come from tools alone. It comes from how well those tools are connected, integrated, managed, and aligned with business goals.

Real transformation happens when strategy, architecture, processes, and execution all work together. Without this connection, even the best tools may not deliver real value.

The SAP Integrated Tool Chain, especially within the RISE with SAP approach, is a powerful way to support business transformation. It provides visibility, traceability, and structure to transformation work-helping projects move faster, stay in control, and align better with business needs.

What Is the SAP Integrated Tool Chain?

The SAP Integrated Tool Chain is a set of tools and platforms that support every stage of your transformation journey- Discover, Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy, and Run. These tools are not isolated. They are connected, so information flows smoothly across business process modeling, enterprise architecture, development, testing, and adoption.

The tool chain covers five important workstreams:

  • Business Process Management
  • Enterprise Architecture
  • Change and Enablement
  • Build and Monitor
  • Digital Backbone and Operations (managing core systems and ongoing operations)

Integrated Tool Chain For Rise With SAP

These workstreams cover the entire RISE with SAP project lifecycle to keep everything aligned.

Why the SAP Integrated Tool Chain Matters?

Today, businesses need to change quickly while keeping things clear and avoiding mistakes. The SAP Integrated Tool Chain helps by:

  • Connecting all parts of a project‚Äîfrom planning and designing processes to building, testing, and training‚Äîso everything works well together.
  • Making sure teams have the latest information and stay on the same page.
  • Helping teams make better decisions, finish tasks faster, and improve quality.

From an architect‚Äôs view, linking all parts:

  • Keeps business goals clear and visible.
  • Makes sure all teams work toward the same results.
  • Cuts down confusion and stops work from being repeated.
  • Helps the company get value faster and keep growing.

Business Transformation Management Via Integrated tool chain

What Architects Need to Know about Toolchain Components?

I tried to put together how the SAP Integrated Tool Chain tools align with the RISE with SAP journey.

This structure helps enterprise and solution architects understands which tools are used when, what value they deliver and how to guide their usage based on business goals, complexity and readiness.

  • SAP LeanIX: Shows the IT landscape like applications and integrations, connects them to business capabilities, and helps plan future scenarios. Used in Discover -> Prepare -> Explore (also in Realize to track initiatives). For the architect, it gives a clear view of the current state and guides decisions on what to keep, retire, or modernize.
  • SAP Signavio (Process Insights, Process Manager, Process Navigator): Finds problems in processes, designs better future processes, and supports standardization. Used in Discover -> Explore -> Realize (also in Run for ongoing improvements). For the architect, it brings transparency, aligns process design with business goals, and helps set KPIs and track results.
  • SAP Cloud ALM + Tricentis Test Automation: Manages project tasks, governance, and traceability, and automates testing to ensure quality and lower risks. Used in Prepare -> Realize -> Deploy -> Run. For the architect, it gives visibility into project status, enforces quality gates, and keeps the project aligned with business processes.
  • SAP Enable Now & WalkMe: Provides training, simulations, and in-app guidance to improve user adoption and reduce resistance. Used in Realize -> Deploy -> Run. For the architect, it ensures users adopt the new processes and tools, helping close the gap between deployment and business value.

Behind the Design: An Architect‚Äôs Analysis

From an architect‚Äôs point of view, the SAP Integrated Tool Chain helps in these important ways:

  • See the Big Picture from the Start - With SAP Signavio and LeanIX, you get a clear view of current business processes and application landscapes, which sets a strong foundation for the project.
  • Make Smart Decisions with Real Data - LeanIX shows which applications support business goals and where there‚Äôs overlap, helping you make decisions based on real value.
  • Improve Processes, Don‚Äôt Just Copy Them - SAP Signavio helps optimize existing processes, so you‚Äôre not just copying old processes as-is. This makes testing, training, and future improvements easier.
  • Keep Your Core System Clean and Flexible - SAP BTP lets you build necessary extensions outside the core ERP, keeping the system manageable and flexible.
  • Keep Everything Connected and Easy to Track - SAP Cloud ALM links requirements, testing, defects, and process models, so changes are always traceable and aligned.
  • Catch Problems Early and Improve Quality - Tricentis Test Automation finds issues early in the process. SAP Enable Now and WalkMe help train users and reduce post-go-live problems.
  • Keep Getting Better Even After Launch - The tool chain continues to support monitoring, feedback, and ongoing improvements, helping your business adapt and grow.

 

From Strategy to Execution

 

Leveraging Toolchain Integrations

By connecting these tools, architects create a seamless flow of information from strategy to execution to adoption. Each integration reduces manual effort, aligns business and IT, and ensures continuous improvement throughout the transformation journey.

Here are some of the key integrations:

  • Cloud ALM to LeanIX: Cloud ALM provides solution landscape data to LeanIX, auto-populating the application repository with systems and lifecycle details.
  • LeanIX to Signavio and Signavio to LeanIX:
    • From LeanIX to Signavio: Application and lifecycle details are linked to process steps.
    • From Signavio to LeanIX: Process hierarchies are shared back, enabling architects to analyze dependencies.
  • LeanIX to Cloud ALM: Transformation initiatives planned in LeanIX (e.g. app replacements, new rollouts) are handed to Cloud ALM as concrete projects with tasks, milestones, and owners.
  • Signavio to Cloud ALM: To-be process models from Signavio are synchronized into Cloud ALM, where they drive requirements, specifications, and test cases‚Äîall tied to the originating process.
  • Cloud ALM to Tricentis and Tricentis to CALM : Cloud ALM orchestrates automated tests built in Tricentis, while Tricentis executes them. Results flow back into Cloud ALM for reporting and tracking.
  • Signavio to WalkMe and Walkme to Signavio: Signavio mines backend logs to show process execution, while WalkMe captures frontend user behavior. Together, they provide a 360¬∞ view of process performance and adoption.
  • WalkMe to LeanIX: WalkMe shares application usage insights (frequency, friction points) with LeanIX, enriching architecture views with adoption data.
  • WalkMe Adoption Layer: WalkMe overlays live guidance in SAP Fiori, automating steps, and measuring whether users follow processes as designed.

Interfaces between SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio, SAP Cloud ALM and WalkMe

Final Thoughts: Architecture-Led Transformation is the Future

The SAP Integrated Tool Chain is evolving into a powerful ecosystem that enables enterprise architects to guide, govern, and accelerate transformation. It‚Äôs no longer about isolated tools‚Äîit‚Äôs about intelligent integration across strategy, design, execution, and adoption.

For architects, this means the ability to:

  • Drive clarity across complexity
  • Translate strategy into action
  • Align business, IT, and operations
  • Govern with data and visibility
  • Build for change, not just for go-live

It‚Äôs not enough to simply implement applications anymore‚Äîwe must deliver measurable business outcomes. With the Integrated Tool Chain, supported by RISE with SAP, we now have the methodology, tools, and structure to make that vision a reality.

Note: The images are available also in our public document and in our white paper

entry.title: üåü Highlights: Enterprise Architects Guide on SAP BW Modernization üåü
entry.content:
We wrapped up an in-depth session ‚Äì expertly introduced by Gaurish ‚Äì on ‚ÄúArchitecting your SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Journey from Data to Intelligence." Sandy, Justin, and Jason shared practical viewpoints for anyone charting a course from legacy SAP BW to the world of SAP‚Äôs Business Data Cloud.

üîç Why Modernize SAP BW?
Justin emphasized how SAP BW has shaped enterprise analytics for 25+ years. However, remaining on legacy systems increases risks and costs, while stifling innovation. The move to modern, multi-cloud data platforms is essential to sustain business continuity and stay competitive.

üöÄ Unveiling the SAP Business Data Cloud Advantage
Modernizing to BDC offers a unified and scalable SaaS platform that blends SAP and non-SAP data, infuses AI and machine learning, and boosts analytics and data governance. It preserves business relationships and metadata, providing more business context than ever possible with classic BW.

üõ£Ô∏è Strategic Pathways & Migration Options
Successful modernization starts with a BW landscape assessment. SAP supports this with a free assessment and discovery workshop to catalogue your environment and match the right transition pathway‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs greenfield, system conversion, or embedded scenarios. Focus is on minimizing business disruption and maximizing long-term agility.

üõ†Ô∏è The Data Product Generator in Action
Sandy‚Äôs live demo showed how the Data Product Generator lets organizations extract BW InfoProvider data into SAP Datasphere‚Äôs object store - supporting cost-effective storage and simplified creation of data products ready for analytics and AI in Databricks, Datashare, and more.

üîó Smooth BW-BDC Transitions & Reference Patterns
The ability to push data from BW into BDC via dedicated inbound spaces, define granular subscriptions, and link to intelligent applications in SAC allows gradual, disruption-minimized modernization. Sandy outlined technical steps, naming conventions, and how semantic information and associations enhance downstream analytics.

üèõÔ∏è Enterprise Architecture Viewpoints
Jason gave a holistic lens on this transformation, urging enterprise architects to align their strategy on security, governance, business stakeholder impact, and organizational change management. Modernization isn‚Äôt just about technology‚Äîit‚Äôs about culture, skills, and sustainable strategic alignment.

üéâ Customer Success, Services & What‚Äôs Next
SAP‚Äôs BDC Discovery Workshop and free readiness assessment were spotlighted‚Äîhelping organizations begin their modernization journey with confidence. Participants gained clarity on prerequisites for custom data products, and how future capabilities like the Data Product Studio will shape self-service data management.

SAP Migration Assessment: https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/sap-migration-assessment.html

üôåHuge thanks to everyone who joined and asked great questions! Special thanks to Sandy for the impromptu deep dive and hands-on demo.


üëâStay tuned for the next session: ‚ÄúFast Track to SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äù featuring fresh perspectives from the Data & Analytics community.

Registration Link: https://events.sap.com/eaa-bdc-apac/en_us/home.html#accordion-5d79451476-item-7fc89659c4

 @Gaurish-Dessai  @SandyTran @Justin_Zhang1

entry.title: Integrating SAP Datasphere with S/4HANA in ECS
entry.content:
Integrating SAP S/4 HANA with Datasphere in ECS:

Introduction

In today's data-driven business landscape, seamless integration between enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems and advanced analytics platforms is crucial for unlocking real-time insights and driving informed decision-making. SAP Datasphere, a cloud-based data management solution, offers powerful capabilities for data modelling, federation, and replication. SAP Datasphere integration enables SAP S/4HANA system and the organizations to harmonize data from core business operations with broader analytics workflows, all, while maintaining security and compliance.

Objective of this guide is to serve as a walkthrough guide for integrating S/4HANA system  with SAP Datasphere. However, please note that this guide is for information purpose only and the configuration steps in customers‚Äô responsibility should be followed up by the customers accordingly.

Architecture Diagram

Prerequisites for Integration

Before diving into the setup, please note that, for the convenience of this guide and to be in sync with the terms, here on, we will assume S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition at ECS as S/4HANA system. Which also implies customer‚Äôs current landscape (when referred as on-premise) is ‚ÄòECS‚Äô- a managed private cloud.

  1. SAP Datasphere Service Instance: Customer should have already completed the onboarding of SAP Datasphere. It runs on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
  2. Data Provisioning (DP) Agent:  Required for handling remote table data flow between on-premise and cloud. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  3. SAP Cloud Connector: Required to securely expose on-premise systems to the cloud without opening firewalls (reverse invoke) used for replication and live data flow connections. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  4. Network and Access: All applicable secure network connections between S/4HANA and Datasphere based on relevant dataflows to be taken care.
    Ex: CC for inbound dataflows from BTP to ECS and outbound internet proxy for outbound traffic from ECS to Datasphere. Also IP allowlisting for the DP Agent server and likewise.

4.1       IP allowlisting Process:

In order to connect ECS instance to datasphere tenant, it requires public IP associated with customer network‚Äôs internet proxy of the ECS servers to be added in IP allowlist tab in datasphere.

This is the public IP of their CGS proxy server. Customer can follow KBA 3643152 to get this public IP.

After getting this IP, log in to Datasphere tenantÔÉ† System ÔÉ† Configuration ÔÉ† IP Allowlist ÔÉ† Trusted Ips

 

  • SAP Notes and Add-ons: Implement relevant SAP Notes (e.g., 3283282 for CDS views, 3016862 for ABAP integration) in S/4HANA system and ensure the DMIS add-on is available for replication scenarios.
  • SICF services for live connection : Ensure all SICF services under the node /sap/bw/ina are activated in the S/4HANA system.
  • User Permissions: Administrative access in Datasphere, S/4HANA, and BTP

Integration Steps

The integration process involves configuring connectivity, setting up agents, and creating connections in Datasphere. Here's a detailed technical walkthrough

Step 1: Set Up Spaces in SAP Datasphere

  • Navigate to Space Management in Datasphere.
  • Create a new space and assign users to it. This space will host your data models and connections.

 

Step 2: Register and Configure the Data Provisioning Agent

  • In Datasphere, go to System > Configuration > Data Integration and create an On-Premise Agent.
  • Note the agent details: Name, HANA server (host), port, username, and password for messaging.
  • On the DP Agent server:
    • Run ./agentcli.sh ‚ÄìconfigAgent in the /usr/sap/<SID>/dataprovagent/bin directory.

    • Select SAP HANA Connection > 7. Connect to SAP Datasphere via JDBC.

 

  1. Specify the details according to information provided by customer:
  1. Name of the agent instance.
  2. Set " true" to use an encrypted connection over JDBC.
  3. Specify the hostname and port for the  SAP Datasphere  instance.
    • Hostname: <instance_name>.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • Port Number: 443
  4. As SAP Datasphere is situated outside the ECS network infrastructure, a proxy is required for HTTPS communication. Define the default CGS proxy host - proxy:3128 (no authentication required)
  5. Provide the authentication credentials for the HANA User for Agent Messaging.
  6.  Confirm to save the agent connection settings. With that any existing agent connection settings are overwritten.

  • Restart the DP Agent.
  • Enable required adapters (e.g., ABAPAdapter for S/4HANA).

 

Step 3: Configure SAP Cloud Connector

  • To configure cloud connector we need the information of Datasphere‚Äôs internal Subaccount details. This can be found under Datasphere tenant, System ÔÉ† Administration ÔÉ†Data source Configuration ÔÉ† SAP BTP Core Account

        

 

  • If the email ID which will be used to setup cloud connector is not visible under the Subaccount User header, use the Change/Add Cloud Platform User option to the respective ID.
  • Under the Live Data Sources header select the ‚ÄòAllow live data to securely leave my network‚Äô option
  • Under On-Premise Data Sources header add the location ID you will be using in your cloud connector if any.

 

  • Add the subaccount in Cloud connector using the Subaccount ID, Region Host and user information from above.
  • Add the same location ID as configured in the previous step.

  • Add your on-premise S/4HANA system in the Cloud Connector:
    • Use HTTPS and RFC protocols.
    • System type: ABAP.
    • For HTTPS ‚Äú/‚Äù URL path needs to be exposed for all Paths and Sub-Paths
    • For RFC protocol add resources as below-
      • ‚ÄòDHAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòDHAPE_‚Äô with prefix for CDS view extraction.
      • ‚ÄòLTAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòLTAPE_‚Äô with prefix option for accessing tables with SLT.
      • ‚Äò/SAPDS/‚Äô with prefix option for accessing data with ODP.
      • Add RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH with exact name option for all three options.
  • Ensure both RFC and HTTPS resources are reachable.

Step 4: Prepare S/4HANA for Connectivity

  • Create a TCP/IP RFC connection in S/4HANA using program ID IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER.
  • Register the program at the OS level: rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &.
  • Test the RFC connection.

Step 5: Create the Connection in SAP Datasphere to S/4H

To create live data connection from datasphere to backend S4 system in ECS, it uses SSH tunnel via Cloud connector

In your Datasphere space, select System > Configuration ÔÉ† Data Integration.

  • Go to Live Data Connections (Tunnel) click on ‚ÄúManage Live Data Connections‚Äù  A window opens click on ‚Äú+‚Äù a pop up opens, select SAP S/4 HANA

  • For live data: using a Tunnel connection enter the Location ID maintained in Cloud connector
  • Input application server details, system number, client ID, SID,
  • Provide S/4HANA username and password.

 

 

 

After you click on Ok it adds the connection

 

Step 6: Set Up Data Flows and Models

  • Use Remote Tables for federation or Replication Flows for data replication (supporting initial and delta loads via CDC).
  • Import CDS views using the Model Import Wizard to automatically bring in metadata and semantics.

entry.title: Japan Bank Charges in Payment Run
entry.content:
This blog post introduces the procedure of payments with the bank charges through a payment run in Contract Accounting. This solution is available for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

According to the contract, your contract partner, who provides the goods or services, covers the bank charges. This blog post introduces customizing activities and how they influence payment processing.

Master Data Settings

In the contract account level, you set up the cost allocation key and the instruction key.

  1. Open the contract account master date in the transaction CAA1 (Create) or transaction CAA2 (Edit).
  2. Based on the agreement between you and your contract partner, you can select the following instruction keys for Payment run:
    • D2 with bank charge: Bank charges covered by the contract partner
    • D1 without bank charge: Bank charges covered by the company
    • Leave the field empty if no bank charge is applied

Customizing Activities

Activating the business function ‚Äì FICA_LOC_JP1

You must activate the business function to use the functions for Japan bank charges in Contract Accounting.

In the SFW5 transaction, double click the FICA_LOC_JP1 business function entry and activate it.

Activating Japan Bank Charge for Company Code

After you activated the business function in your system, you can switch on the Japan bank charges feature for specific company codes.

  1. Go to the Set Up Company Codes for Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable activity (view: TFK001B).
  2. Double click the entry of the company code.
  3. In the Country/Region-specific Functions select the Activate Settings for JP (Bank Charges) checkbox.

Activating Bank Charge for Document Type

In this activity, you activate bank charges for payment runs.

  1. Go to the Activate Bank Charges activity (view: V_TFK_JP_BCH).
  2. Enter the values for the payment run:

    Sample values:
    Application AreaCompany CodeHouse BankCurrencyDocument Origin
    C ‚Äì Convergent FI-CA<Your Company Code><Your Company Code>JPY

    06 ‚Äì Payment run

     

Determining accounts for bank charges

In this activity you post attributes assignment to include a tax determination for bank charge.

  1. In the transaction FQC0, enter 1111 in the posting area field and the Chart of accounts.
  2. Assign a G/L account and tax determination.

Defining Transfer Type for the Company Code and House Bank

In this activity you select a payment transfer type, such as domestic electronic bank transfer or domestic bank transfer by mail for the payment run.

  1. In the Parameters for DMEs and foreign payment transaction (view V_T012D_CORE), enter the company code and the house bank.
  2. In the Running Mode, you can decide how the payment is made.
    If you select the By Letter checkbox, the transfer type is domestic bank transfer by mail. Otherwise, the transfer type is domestic electronic bank transfer.
    Note: This checkbox selection is used in the following customizing activity ‚Äì Bank charges determination (view: V_T042J).

Defining Bank Charges

In this activity, you can define amounts of bank charges for each set-up threshold based on the transfer types and bank types.

  1. In the Bank Charges Determination (view , enter the paying company code and the house bank.
    Note: This view is also used in Financial Accounting.
  2. You can define the threshold for bank charges based on the settings:
    • Bank type: Between the sender‚Äôs or the receiver‚Äôs bank the bank type can be (1) same bank and same branch, (2) same bank but different branches, or (3) different banks.
    • Transfer type: the transfer type must be consistent to the previous customizing activity. For example, if you select the By Letter checkbox, You cannot select other transfer type other than the domestic bank transfer by mail.
    • Currency: For bank charges, only the currency JPY is available.
    • From amount: set up the threshold from which the bank charge amount is applied. This threshold amount refers to the invoice amount plus VAT.

Assigning Payment Methods for Japan Bank Charges

In this activity assign the instruction key to the payment method used for Japan bank charges.

Open the transaction FQP1 at the Instruction key level you must assign the instruction key to the payment method used for JP Bank charges.
Maintain the Cost Allocation Key column to determine who pays the bank charges for the corresponding instruction key.

If bank charges are not required, the standard process is applied.

Procedure of Processing Payments

  1. You, as a company, post documents for outgoing payments with the invoice amount, for example, 5,000 JPY.
  2. Execute a payment run, that clears the paid open items
    Note: Only the payment method with direct clearing is supported.
  3. You generate payment file. In the payment medium file, the payment amount is already deducted by the bank charge. For example, if the bank charge is 215 JPY, the payment amount is 4,785 JPY. (See the payment file example below.)
  4. Send the payment file to the bank for the customer to arrange the payment.
  5. After transferring the payment based on the payment file, the bank sends you a bank statement file with realized payment of amount 4,785 JPY.
Example of Payment Medium Format with Bank Charges

Is this blog post useful to you? Leave your comments to let us know your thoughts.

entry.title: Re: Dunning per Mail/Printing only if there is no Mail-Ad...
entry.content: Hello @FabianSCC, Correct, you should not fill the Standard E-Mail Address column in your OPD table for this requirement. That filed is only used to force a fixed recipient, which from my understanding is not what you need. Instead, when maintaining the Channel step in the Output Parameter Determination app, use the Condition Fields dropdown and select Default E-Mail Address as your condition. Then build as previously mentioned two separate determination rules. The fallback should work correctly thereafter. Best regards Chris

entry.title: Re: Planned vs Unplanned Depreciation Behavior after Post...
entry.content:
Hi @archana_raut38 ,

Below is my inline response to your requirement.

Step/ScenarioWhat You DidSystem Behavior (Observed)Standard SAP Behavior (Cloud Public Edition)Recommendation
AcquisitionCreated asset with 100,000 acquisition, 10-year useful life, depreciation key LINSPlanned depreciation = 10,000/yearCorrect ‚Üí LINS distributes depreciation automaticallyKeep depreciation key as LINS (or similar automatic key)
Unplanned DepreciationTried posting 20,000 unplanned depreciation. Changed depreciation key to Manual temporarilyAllowed posting, but automatic planned depreciation stoppedNot recommended. Manual key disables periodic depreciation in CloudDo not change key. Use ‚ÄúPost Unplanned Depreciation‚Äù app (or Post to Asset Journal) with LINS still active
Switch Back KeyAfter posting unplanned depreciation, switched back from Manual ‚Üí LINSSystem throws error due to mismatchStandard check in Cloud: prevents inconsistent valuesKeep automatic depreciation key active from the start
Change Useful LifeAfter unplanned depreciation, reduced useful life from 10 ‚Üí 8 yearsError occurred when combined with manual key switchNormally: Cloud recalculates automatically: Remaining NBV √∑ Remaining useful lifeFirst post unplanned depreciation, then adjust useful life. System spreads NBV accordingly
Client RequirementBoth: (a) Automatic periodic depreciation, and (b) Ability to post extraordinary depreciationNot possible when switching keysCloud supports both, but only when using correct apps (not key switching)Use automatic depreciation key (LINS) + supported Fiori apps for unplanned depreciation + change useful life after

Summary:
-What you observed is standard system behavior in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
-Do not switch depreciation keys.
-Always keep automatic key (e.g., LINS).
-Use Unplanned Depreciation Fiori apps to record extraordinary depreciation.
-Then adjust useful life ‚Üí system will re-spread remaining NBV automatically.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh
